results.title: Folk, Rhythm and Life
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Skermer Famliy have been running the Bilyana ‘Folk Rhythm & Life Festival’, in north-eastern Victoria, since 1996 and in the process raising funds for local and international charities. The festival has always been environmentally sustainable, with the original “drop dunnies” developed by Hamish Skermer now being used not only in Eldorado but also at festivals in Australia and overseas.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI

results.title: The Eldorado Museum
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Sue Phillips, Sandra Buchan and Geoff Milne take us on a tour of the Eldorado Museum and share the rich history of the pioneering families who established infrastructure and made the northern Victorian town of Eldorado what it is in 2012.

results.title: Artists of Eldorado
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet local artists Maureen Hearn, Denise Ellison, Thea Day, Sandra Buchan and Sam Anderson, and learn about their inspirations and artistic practice. Moved by the magic of Eldorado, in northern Victoria, these artists are never short of inspiration. Day, Ellison and Buchan make time each week to get together and share their passion for painting and line drawing. Hearn works out of her studio that showcases her love of the river and obsession with chickens. Anderson is a metal sculptor who works on his family farm creating large scale works, such as his ‘Gorilla’, which must be seen to be believed.

results.title: The Greta Swamp
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: The area surrounding Greta, in north-eastern Victoria, used to be a swamp, home to indigenous wildlife and the mythical Bunyip creature. The swamp was drained as part of a government employment project in the 1890s, leaving behind rich fertile land ideal for grazing, however it also created a complete change in the area around Greta, especially in the hill country, causing environmental damage. One hundred years on and local Land Care members Anthony and David Griffiths, along with 2012 Land Care President Phil Gottschling, have dedicated their time and energy to try and reverse the effects of the dredging and are revegetating their land to restore balance to the environment.

results.title: Greta Craft Group
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Women come from great distances bringing their knitting needles, sewing machines and a good yarn to the weekly Greta Craft Group. The group was started by Kath White in the early 1990s when, as a young mum and new to the area, she reached out to other mums for some companionship. The group grew from there and became so popular they needed a waiting list for those interested to join - as Winifred Suffield suggests “craft is just an excuse to meet”. 2012 President Helen Bird and long time members Nola Jones and Julie White, speak about the support and friendship that the group has provided over decades. We hear the sounds of laughter and chatter as the ladies make all sorts of beautiful crafts which they provide to charities, both locally and internationally.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI

results.title: The Greta Bunyip Newsletter
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: In the digital age it’s all well and good for those who are connected via high speed internet, but in some rural towns it is the good old fashioned newsletter that keeps locals in the know. The Bunyip Newsletter is hand-delivered across the wider Greta area by six committed volunteers. We meet Noeleen Lloyd and Allan Porker as well as local historian Joan Ellis and hear about the importance of having a local newsletter. ‘The Bunyip’ was born out of a demand from the locals to be better informed and more connected to their community and surrounds. Over 300 newsletters are distributed every two months containing articles of historical, sporting and community importance.

results.title: Cook's Family Farm
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet the Cook family and spend time with three generations as they muster and milk cows. Robert and Patricia are the proud parents of five grown up sons and 22 grandchildren. Brothers, Ross and Steve Cook have returned to share-farm with their mum and dad and there is no other place they would rather be. Surrounded by rolling hills and the winery county of the King Valley in northern Victoria, the Cook family have worked hard to keep and grow their dairy farm.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI

results.title: The Whitlands Plateau
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Distance is no barrier to this active group of entrepreneurs who have a rich history and a strong community spirit. From lawyers and artists to viticulturists and wine makers, the small plateau in Whitlands, in north-eastern Victoria, attracts a diverse group of talented and hard working professionals. We meet some life-long locals and a newcomer to town and hear about the history of the area as well as the ventures that are being undertaken in 2012 Whitlands.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI

results.title: The Pizzini Family
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: This is a story about an Italian-Australian family made unique by three generations of winemakers and master chefs. Meet Natalie, Alfred, Arnold, Katrina, Carla and matriarch Rosetta Pizzini, hear about the four brothers that immigrated to Australia and started farming tobacco, eventually diversifying to growing Italian variety grapes. The Pizzini’s make their own wine, run a cooking school and manage a boutique hotel in Whitfield, but still the most important part of their day is when they sit together and share a meal, a glass of wine and a laugh.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI

results.title: Bus number 3
results.creator_credit: Zhou Hua, Lei Zulin, Luo Tai, Wang Jiayue and Changchun Film Studio
results.brief_description:
Number 3 bus is a story which puts certain relevance on the revolution of new technology for buses in China in 1979. On public Bus Number 3, two ticket inspectors Qing and Huang face their jobs with different levels of professionalism and demeanours. Qing is patient, professional and helpful; she always receives compliments and praises from customers. Huang is the opposite; rude, hot-tempered and overall frustrated with his responsibilities as the ‘station-caller’. Bus driver Hong is most aggravated by the bustling intersection she crosses every afternoon because Bai, the traffic controller, always seem to stop her in her tracks. The clouds of smoke fuming from her bus after every jolting halt at the intersection seem to reflect her sizzling annoyance.
Amongst the many passengers who board the bus, never did the three bus workers realize that one particular young “frequent” passenger named Gu, was about to change their lives and push the evolution of technologies. Gu made extraordinary observations on the happenings of workers and passengers of Number 3 bus and realises that “quarrels” and issues often arise because workers’ voices are strained when they work as station-callers; and their attitude and energy are used to its very last drop while they perform their monotonous roles with no respite every day. Subsequently, Gu invents a loud speaker and presents it as a gift to the working troupe on Number 3 bus. Huang was touched by Gu’s genuine act of altruism and both he and Qing joins Gu in his efforts to revolutionise technology thereafter.
During a socializing event, Hong and Bai had an encounter face-to-face and developed as friends. Thereon in, Bai makes sure that Hong meets a green light every time her bus arrives at the intersection that he controls. As Bai outwardly favours Bus number 3 at the intersection, it sparked public outrage and he was reported to his supervisor. As a result, Gu steps up to help Bai and assisted the traffic police in developing automated traffic lights to restore peace in the community.
While the innovation of technology takes flight, the group of youngsters develops a strong friendship bond. During a little outing at the park, Huang brings his girlfriend (Lan) and Hong and Bai reveals that they too have just got together. Everyone seems to have paired up like lovebirds but Gu only has thoughts for science and technology innovation; subsequently, he does not realize Qing has thoughts only for him. Huang looks on and knew that he had to do something to help both his friends. In the end, Huang sneakily comes up with a plan of using the electronic recorder (which Gu had invented) to record Gu’s private confession of love for Qing.
The next day, while Gu and Qing goes for a walk in the park, Huang tails the couple with a group of friends. When Gu finally tries to sit down to confess his love for Qing, he loses his courage and could only mumble gobbledygook. Huang finally intervenes behind the bush and plays the recording which he had cunningly recorded out in public.
The group of like-minded group of youngsters blossomed in friendship and love while pushing the development of technology innovation. United in heart and mind, they were able to equip an automatic station-calling recorder on the Number 3 bus and simultaneously see the installation of traffic lights emerge at the bustling intersection. On the wide roads of China, we see the city moving forward towards a brighter future like the smooth momentum of the Number 3 Bus.

Cultural History of the film:
This film captures beautiful images of Shanghai in its 80s. It shows China just reconnecting with the rest of the world after being through the politically radical period of the Cultural Revolution. Of note, the Chang Chun Film Studio was the first registered film factory under the People’s Republic of China. As this film was created in 1979, it is believed to be one of the early batches of Chinese films which were allowed to be more flexible in its content — striding away from films that predominantly promote Communist ideals, notions of class struggle and continuous revolution after the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Communist Party Conference in December 1978. At the time, Deng Xiaoping promoted the slogan “emancipation of the mind” and allowed the development of more creative ideas — opening a crack of opportunity and flexibility for filmmakers to create films that entertained (provided that their intention to make commercialized movies were not obvious).
To a certain extent, this film celebrates the country veering from the stringent eras of the Cultural Revolution, which removed an entire generation from access to university and professional training in the scientific work force. During the late 1970s, the evolving structure of science and technology under the People’s Republic mostly thrived from the achievements of poorly educated civilians; hence this film significantly reflects the situation of the development of science and technology in China while the effects of Cultural Revolution slowly loosen its grip on their youngsters.

My own afterthoughts:
This is a wonderfully entertaining film which also hopes to showcase how the country continues to thrive in their development of science and technology, even though most civilian’s education and certification standards were not high. I can’t help but also think the film also serves to boost national spirit while it shows young people full of vigor and vitality in the film. Personally, there almost seems to be a subtextual reading which highlights to viewers that youngsters are the key to China’s future and the nation’s hopes are placed on them. I would also like to add that the meaning of the Chinese title for this film is ‘Youngster’ if translated directly into English.
(3 stars - Pearl Lau; November 13, 2012)

While the innovation of technology takes flight, the group of youngsters develops a strong friendship bond. During a little outing at the park, Huang brings his girlfriend (Lan) and Hong and Bai reveals that they too have just got together. Everyone seems to have paired up like lovebirds but Gu only has thoughts for science and technology innovation; subsequently, he does not realize Qing has thoughts only for him. Huang looks on and knew that he had to do something to help both his friends. In the end, Huang sneakily comes up with a plan of using the electronic recorder (which Gu had invented) to record Gu’s private confession of love for Qing.
The next day, while Gu and Qing goes for a walk in the park, Huang tails the couple with a group of friends. When Gu finally tries to sit down to confess his love for Qing, he loses his courage and could only mumble gobbledygook. Huang finally intervenes behind the bush and plays the recording which he had cunningly recorded out in public.
The group of like-minded group of youngsters blossomed in friendship and love while pushing the development of technology innovation. United in heart and mind, they were able to equip an automatic station-calling recorder on the Number 3 bus and simultaneously see the installation of traffic lights emerge at the bustling intersection. On the wide roads of China, we see the city moving forward towards a brighter future like the smooth momentum of the Number 3 Bus.

Cultural History of the film:
This film captures beautiful images of Shanghai in its 80s. It shows China just reconnecting with the rest of the world after being through the politically radical period of the Cultural Revolution. Of note, the Chang Chun Film Studio was the first registered film factory under the People’s Republic of China. As this film was created in 1979, it is believed to be one of the early batches of Chinese films which were allowed to be more flexible in its content — striding away from films that predominantly promote Communist ideals, notions of class struggle and continuous revolution after the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Communist Party Conference in December 1978. At the time, Deng Xiaoping promoted the slogan “emancipation of the mind” and allowed the development of more creative ideas — opening a crack of opportunity and flexibility for filmmakers to create films that entertained (provided that their intention to make commercialized movies were not obvious).
To a certain extent, this film celebrates the country veering from the stringent eras of the Cultural Revolution, which removed an entire generation from access to university and professional training in the scientific work force. During the late 1970s, the evolving structure of science and technology under the People’s Republic mostly thrived from the achievements of poorly educated civilians; hence this film significantly reflects the situation of the development of science and technology in China while the effects of Cultural Revolution slowly loosen its grip on their youngsters.

My own afterthoughts:
This is a wonderfully entertaining film which also hopes to showcase how the country continues to thrive in their development of science and technology, even though most civilian’s education and certification standards were not high. I can’t help but also think the film also serves to boost national spirit while it shows young people full of vigor and vitality in the film. Personally, there almost seems to be a subtextual reading which highlights to viewers that youngsters are the key to China’s future and the nation’s hopes are placed on them. I would also like to add that the meaning of the Chinese title for this film is ‘Youngster’ if translated directly into English.
(3 stars - Pearl Lau; November 13, 2012)
